text: It has been a while since I've last
talked about Lords of the Fallen on this
channel. The last time being over a year
ago when I made a comparison to Lies of
P. In that video, I did have a scoring
system to determine which was better out
of the two. And Liz P did just slightly
win that battle. And honestly, looking
back at it, I probably should have made
the scoring system a little different
because I think Lizipe is the much
better game from a technical standpoint
and just overall how more polished it
is. But I did say that Lords of the
Fallen had a handful of things that it
did better, like the combat system,
which people got mad at me because they
assumed I meant like the overall combat
when I was specifically just talking
about the combat system because overall
combat in a Souls game relies heavily on
how good the enemy and bosses are, which
Lords of the Fallen didn't really do
that as well. But the combat system and
overall build creation is really good
and I think better. You have the best
spell system or ranged weapon system
that I've ever seen in a Souls game. You
get a forgiving dodge. You get
deflecting, dual wielding, shields for
the sword and board play styles, and
with things like its variety of build
types, the rune system, extremely
interesting sets of rings and pendants,
it makes the build creation probably the
best part about the game. I kind of wish
the economy wasn't so bad to where I had
to break the bank every single time I
leveled up a weapon. This part of the
game was like so annoying and it was to
the point that my level one run was my
most enjoyable playthrough because I
could just spend my vigor how I wanted.
Now, the second best part of the game,
in my opinion, is the overall aesthetic.
The cool gothic fantasy world with like
the over-the-top scenery, enemy designs,
and armor sets, which yes, you can
actually customize the colors of. It's
all very visually pleasing. But as for
the main problems I had with the game,
the major one being the umbra world.
This gimmick mechanic was somewhat
interesting, but in my opinion, it just
made the game flatout worse. It was
responsible for the performance being
really poor. It made it hard to
distinguish certain rooms or areas
because the umbra world looked the exact
same in almost every single location.
The enemy density and distribution was a
problem because you had a system to when
you die or transfer to the umbra world,
it's made it where you not only have so
many enemies but also different types of
enemies in the same room. In other games
where you had different aesthetics of
enemies that would be sprinkled
throughout the game, but in Lords of the
Fallen, you fight almost every enemy the
game is designed in just the first few
areas. So, by the time you get to the
end, you fought the same enemy or reskin
of enemy thousands of times over. And
most people's impressions of a game is
going to be the last one, which the
final area basically added no new
enemies. But worst of all yet, despite
the umber world being marketed as an
option to make the game harder but get
more rewards for most of the game, it
just wasn't optional. You had to go to
the umber world just to progress through
the game because there was some like
basic shitty puzzle in the way. And
there's so many cases where these are
just mandatory to just progress to the
next room. And none of these puzzles
were that complex. Every single one of
these were just like an artificial way
to extend the playing time or just
justify the world's existence, hence it
being a gimmick mechanic. I did have
some more issues when it came to the
things like the enemies or bosses not
being that memorable or fun to fight.
Also, the replay value in some parts of
the level design, specifically the
individual levels. I think the whole
game interconnects are extremely good.
Another issue I had with the game was
the lack of various move sets. There's
about 150 weapons in the game, but
roughly 15 unique move sets amongst all
of them. But yeah, I did have some
problems with those things. I just don't
really want to get too in-d depth
because the main topic of this video is
talking about what are the things that
have changed and is it in a better
state? Because in the last year and a
half, there has been over 40 updates.
So, with all these updates, is it now a
better game? Well, yeah, obviously it
is. After that many updates, you better
hope so. But did it fix a lot of the
main problems that I had with the game?
No, of course not. My problems with the
game were more like fundamental and the
things that did improve upon were pretty
cool. And look, I've played the game
around about seven times. Five when the
game got released, once last year, and
once now as of the 2.0 update. And my
major takeaway from my most recent
playthrough is that the game is pretty
much the same, but smoother and a lot
easier. The devs did focus a lot on the
performance, which that had to be the
top priority. I didn't really talk about
it much, but yeah, the game used to run
like a dookie. And for me, honestly, I
cannot look past that stuff, but it does
make sense that the most important part
about the game is that the game actually
works, which I'm glad to report it does
work. Now, while I didn't experience any
crashes while playing the game on high
settings, not maximum settings, just
high settings. And while streaming in
the borderless windowed mode on my 3080,
I basically never had a stable 60fps.
Even times in the hub world at max I was
getting 40. Some parts of the game still
had lots of like weird texture pop-ins,
specifically in the cutscenes, but
without the streaming in medium
settings, full screen 60fps capped, the
game ran almost perfectly. And even on
the PS5, which yes, I bought the game
for both platforms. The PS5 was
extremely smooth. I didn't really
experience any problems at all. So, I do
applaud the devs for acknowledging the
problems with the game and sticking with
it continuously trying to improve the
performance, balancing, bug fixes, and
backtracking of some of the pretty poor
gameplay choices, like the enemy density
with all those ganks and removing
vestigages from New Game Plus. Now, you
can very well say that all these should
have been part of the game to begin
with, which is definitely true. It
should have been, but they didn't just
fix those things, but they also added a
whole bunch of stuff to the game for
free. a dozen new spells, additional
weapon quest lines to unlock cool
skills, built-in randomizer mode,
in-game modifiers, a way to refight
bosses, and a boss rush mode. And now,
as of this 2.0 version of the game, they
added seamless co-op, the user interface
and HUD improvements, audio
improvements, a way to play with your
friends that don't even own the game,
and a bunch of quality of life updates,
too, which is another thing I didn't
talk about much. The quality of life was
definitely in need of lots of love. But
for me, the most important part about
the update was the reworking of the
character movements. And I do want to
talk about stats. All of the other stuff
is pretty self-explanatory. But the
improved player movements pretty much
extends to the lower recovery frames for
most weapon attacks. They tone down like
the lunge of some of these attacks.
There is a dedicated jump button, which
I thoroughly despise because the button
is also tied to the interact button, and
there's plenty of times where I try to
pick something up or climb a ladder and
I'm just like jumping instead. And it
doesn't seem like there's a way to
actually separate the two. So hopefully
that gets fixed. But also, the tracking
of the weapons is drastically improved.
And I mean like ridiculously so. It
might be like the best melee weapon
tracking I've ever seen in a Cells game.
Like look at this right here. This is a
360Â° running attack. I'm just doing a
regular running attack. But by the time
I start the animation, I could do more
than a full rotation before it even
finishes. Like it definitely feels
noticeably different to control. Now,
does it fix the weird animations? No,
not really. Does it make the boss fights
feel better sometimes? But speaking of
the boss fights, I know they did have an
update some time ago that buffed the
boss's health and damage, but nerfed
enemy ganks. So, it felt like the boss
fights were more in line with the areas
when it came to the difficulty. But
honestly, they still felt like they were
a pushover. I was just doing a lot of
damage to them. But one thing I did
notice is that when I finished my
playthrough, I was at level 90. And when
I looked back at my earlier characters,
they finished the game at around about
level 73 or 74. So, there had to have
been an update some time ago that just
improved vigor acquisition, which
inherently just makes the game a bit
easier. Now, if you are still concerned
about the game being easy, as I did
mention a bit earlier, there are some
in-game modifiers that kind of serve
somewhat as like difficulty modifiers.
You have things like increasing enemy
density, perma death, decreased healing,
and less checkpoints, which yes, these
things are definitely going to make the
game harder, but this is still just
artificial difficulty, and you can just
variable implement these things yourself
in your own runs. You don't need the
game to do it for you, but it's still
cool that they actually did do this.
When it comes to the online experience
though, I didn't really get to play much
with like the co-op nor the seamless
co-op at all. I did hear some things
that the seamless co-op isn't really
working that well or there's still like
a lots of network issues. I did like a
couple of PvP games and the network does
seem a lot better than what it once was.
It feels like the first couple days when
the game was released and I was doing
invasions. There was so much rubber
banding, disconnects, the input lag was
insane and none of that was really
present. But the net coding is still
isn't really anything amazing. So in
summary, basically everything I liked or
disliked about the game pretty much
stayed the same except for when it came
to things like performance and replay
value. Those are definitely better now.
The performance although not the best,
it is very manageable and the replay
value is better mainly because of the
randomizer modifier and adding these new
spells. Although one thing I would have
liked to see is having more accessible
respspeing. That would have been pretty
nice. But do I recommend buying the game
if you haven't already played it before?
And honestly, yeah. If you are in need
to scratch that Souls itch, I would get
it. It's definitely one of the better
ones that still fall under the
traditional Souls like RPG because
nowadays all the Soulslike games that we
get are more like action hacken slash
types of games with like these stupid
skill tree customizations which I don't
care for at all. But that is a combo for
another day. But now is a better time
than ever to purchase the game because
it is currently 70% off. And it still is
cool to support devs that really care
about their games. Despite this probably
being like a big PR move to just get
some like more game developer cred
because yeah, between the first Lords of
the Fallen game and the release of the
second one, you lost a lot of interest
from a lot of people. So if you actually
want more people to play the sequel that
was announced, something has got to
give. And consistent updates that give
stuff for free is definitely one of
those things to give. So yeah, it's
pretty cool. But anyway, that's
everything that I wanted to cover in
this one. See you guys.
